Tap at Biero. Exceptional beer. Aromas of caramel, pine, bread, and biscuits. Taste has a sweet start, with bitterness taking over for a long finish. Palate is almost creamy, with a medium-to-full body, and a dry finish. Amber, with a frothy head.
Bottle. Red color and nice head. Aroma is hoppy and malty. In mouth both hops and malts play togheter, this beer has complex flavor, but still very good drinkability.

Bottle: Pours a hazed amber-red ale in the glass with a 3 finger tight sand-colored cap..great lacing. Moderate carbonation.

Aroma is subtle but complex...layered malts and layered hopping..simply frikkin gorgeous.

Medium bodied with a rounded character.

Flavor has a rich complexity of malts in front that is almost perfectly balanced with a layered mix of hop varieties....biscuit, toast, bready, sweet dough, toffee meets pine, citrus, floral, herbal woody hopping. Clean and distinctive with a demure complexity...great beer.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2013 Bottle. Dark amber, average mostly diminishing light brown head.  Moderate malty aroma with some sweetness, quite a lot of grapefruit bitterness. Body is medium, flavor has some sweetness and fruitiness with grapefruit bitterness, some caramel. Finish is short to average, malty and dryish, some caramel. Well hoped amber ale, but still this an amber ala. Regardless of IBU/EBU, caramel just do not work for me.

Bottle from Shortys Liquor. Pours a dark amber in colour, wuth a decent off white head. Quite hoppy on the nose, with some orange coming through. Flavour is piney, grassy, citrus, orange peel, and some nuttiness and biscuit.

Flaske: Orange ravfarvet klar øl med et kæmpe skumhoved. Super lækker duft af blomstret humle med en smule tropisk frugt. God bid i smagen der igen er domineret af en god blanding tropisk frugt og engelske blomster. Fremragende øl.
Bottle. Copper beer with a huge dark cream colored head. Grapefruit and malt aroma. Big grapefruit flavor. Medium bodied. Grapefruit and light pine linger with light spice.

Im becoming increasingly fond of Brewdogs lower alcohol beers. This is another solid and flavoursome beer that packs more punch than it should.  Lovely aroma of sweet caramel, fruit and bitterness. The flavour is quite sweet and toasty, caramel, fruit, less bitter than the aroma, but still with a moderate resiny hop finish. FIrm body and mild to moderate carbonation.
Round, hoppy, almost earthy pines. I found this a tad watery. Lots of sappy tobacco, something slightly menthol and tongue numbing. Very easy but slightly lacking.

Keg, Cloisters.  Chewy amber malt nose with lots of leafy dry hops.  Sweet start but gets bitter.  Not a refined lager but a big, leafy, slightly woody, well-integrated tasty one.  One of the better BrewDogs.

Bottle, Morrisons, Carlisle. Good fresh pine aroma, some soapy lemon in there too.  Initially I thought the body was a bit thin for 5% ABV, but, as a previous rating states, it comes into its own the further down the glass you go. 

Very faintly woody, quite dry, nice smooth mouthfeel, good flavoursome finish that lingers well. For me, not the Holy Grail of red ales it claims to be, though.

From bottle. Pours smoothly with an excellent head. Fruity aroma of hoss lemons and apples. Complex hoppy bitterness followed by spicy notes. Dark reddish bronze colour with good clarity, very tempting.

pours brown/amber with good head. Nose is upfront, hoppy pine cones and a hint of nutty roasted goodness. It has a dried cookie note as well as a real fruity goodness. The palate is a bit light considering the aroma. A nice session brew with some good hops for body and a hint of nuttyness to it as well. easy drinking good brew!

330ml bottle. Pours amber/brown with a bubbly tan head and leaves a solid coat of lacing. Spruce needles and fresh toffee on the nose with a roasted note and citrusy punch underneath. Leans way toward butterscotch on the palate with citrus and piney hops through a lengthy bitter finish.
Smooth compared to most British Ruby Ales with a more similar taste to North American ales. Not a particularly challenging ale but great tasting with a long finish

Bottle samples at Chancey Smiths- Deep amber pour with some mahogany hues. Pours a tight eggshell cap. Citric nose has caramel, floral hops, a bit of toast, and banana. Semi sweet from caramel malts with a citric and floral hops bitterness that lingers. A medium bodied amber with assertive carbonation, and a lenghty bitter finish. Good!

aroma of good hops, quite well balanced, although started a bit flat, long lasting taste. Got way better while the glass got more empty (which is often the case, but this time it was a notable difference). Much more body and fullness at the end.

Brown bottle, 11,2 ounces, best before 19/01/11, purchased at Bangor Wine and Cheese on August 17 2010, savoured on October 27 2010; eye: copper with an orangey hue, clear, minimal effervescence, nice beige head, lots of lacing; nose: resinous hops, malt, alcohol, light sox; mouth: resinous hops, malt, alcohol, tea, finale in resinous hops with presence of tea, medium body, good carbonation, mildly bitter, light astringency, lightly grainy texture; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 11,2 onces, meilleure avant 19/01/11, achetée chez Bangor Wine and Cheese le 17 août 2010, savourée le 27 octobre 2010; il : cuivre avec une teinte orangée, claire, effervescence minime, bonne mousse beige, beaucoup de dentelle; nez : houblon résineux, malt, alcool, léger chausson; bouche : houblon résineux, malt, alcool, thé, finale en houblon résineux avec présence de thé, corps moyen, bonne carbonatation, moyennement amère, légère astringence, texture légèrement granuleuse; en résumé : bien bon
Draft. Pours amber with a nice off-white head. Flavor of old hops, massive hop acidity and diacetyl flavor. Just undrinkable. Drain pour.
On tap (33cl) at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo. Ruby/amber colour, nice sticky offwhite foam. Clean, powerful hop aroma with some red fruits. Medium body, refreshing. Pleasantly bitter aftertaste.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Dark golden brown, white head. Aroma of bread, citrus and pine. Taste is toast, malts ,sweet fruit and grapefruit. Nice drinkability

dark walnut pour with a full beige head.  Aroma is aroma is fruity, caramel bread, light vegetative notes.  flavor is mild caramel breadiness, leafy hopiness is light and playful, with some fruitiness as well.  Decent, but not as good as I was expecting, I bet this is incredible when its really really fresh, but some thing is lost in translation

Bottle. Pours a deep reddish brown with about a quarter inch of off-white head. The nose is slightly fruity with  malt and hop notes. The beer has a definite flavor of peated malt with combines nicely the other flavors in the beer. There is a lingering hop bite, but not overpowering. A very drinkable beer that impressed me.

Bottle and tapped: Deep ruby-amber coloured, very stable medium-sized off-white head, sticking to the glass; solid and complex nose of dried fruits, roasted malt and aromatic hops; moderate to solid bitter-sweet flavour, soft MF; distinctive lingering hoppy and toasty finish. A very good beer from a very good brewery......

Bottle from Tysons Whole Foods.  Nice malty, sweet aroma. Pours a clear brownish-red.  Solid slight hop front, with nice malty finish.

One of my favorite 5% alcohol beers ever. I could definitely drink a few of these in a night. Impressed.
Bottle.  Brilliant.  Big resiny American hop aroma and flavour with medium hop bitterness. Good mid-roast maltiness.  Very hoppy for an amber... could equally be a malty IPA.  Nicely balanced.

Medium beige head. Hazy amber body. Spicy resiny tropical fruit aroma with citric pineapple notes. Dry-sweetish resiny pineapple and alcohol taste with wooden citric notes. MId-bodied. Mild, mealy mouthfeel. Dry-bitter grapefruity chalky wooden aftertaste with papery notes. Not bad, but a bit harsh; not their best. A lot of flavour for the alcohol. (0.33l draft at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo.)

Sampled at Brewdog dinner at beerbistro. Pours a beautiful deep ruby with tan frothy head. Lots of caramel malts in the aroma with a citrusy hop smell, taste of caramel malts and bitter hops with a light citrusy and fruity undertone, nice bitter malty finish. A few steps below the hardcore IPA, but nice.

Bottle, sampled at Stockholm Beer and Whiskey Festival 2010. Dark amber colour with medium, off-white head. Hoppy aroma with notes of citrus and grapfruit, some sweetness. Taste is quite malty and sweet, but theres also a great bitterness from the hops. Palate is quite light and a bit watery.

Beautiful deep ruby pour tan frothy head ... lots of lacing ... tons of caramel malts in the aroma with a citrusy hop smell ...... taste of caramel malts and bitter hops with a light citrusy and fruity undertone ... bitter malty finish .... this brew smells and looks amazing but the taste needs to catch up to it ....

UPDATED: APR 19, 2012 Re-rate 4/18/12: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans place. Thanks Tomer G. Clear amber with a beige head. Piney, fruity and citric hops aroma. Flavor has some slightly grainy malt, a bit sweet with a bit of caramel, and a moderately bitter hoppy finish with some pine. Medium-bodied. Nice. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4

Re-rate 3/18/11: Bottle. Clear deep amber with a big off-white head. Aroma of hops - citrus and pine, some biscuits and caramelly notes. Flavor has light malty sweetness with caramelly notes but is mostly dry and hoppy with some fruitiness. Nice bitter finish with grapefruit and some pine. Medium-bodied. Tasty and quaffable. 7/3/7/3/15=3.5

[9/26/10] Bottle at Beer Temple in Amsterdam. Clear amber with a big off-white head. Aroma of citric hops and a bit of malt. Sweetish flavor with butter, light graininess and a bitter hoppy finish. Medium-bodied. 7/3/6/3/13=3.2
Corretta, divertente, morbida, senza troppi guizzi ma una buona birra. Però berla prima della serata scozzese è stata idea pessima.
I coulda sworn I rated this. This is my new favorite amber ale, even though it is so hoppy at times, that its hard to think of it as an amber. Beautiful appearance. Very tasty.

33 cl bottle. Pours clearish red/brown with a big offwhite head and good lace. Smells slightly malty and sweet with a hint of red fruit hoppiness. Tastes lightly malty and sweet with a good bit of red fruit hops, bitter and slightly spicy. Thin body and good carbonation.

33cl bottle. Pours a clear rubish brown color with a big creamy beige head. Long lasting foam. Good lacing. Aroma is intense and complex: citrusy, piny, resiny and pineapple. Some sweet caramel  maltiness too. Taste is similiar: strong citrussy and resiny flavors with a good amount of maltiness(caramel and toffee). Medium-full bodied, good carbonation.

In short: A super-nice extra-light Barley-Wine
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed fresh soon after the beer release
The look: Mahogany body topped by a large beige head with good retention
In long: Nose of caramel, fruity hops and tobacco.  Taste has plenty of caramel, some toffee, lots of citrus fruits,  some tobacco.  Bitterness level is medium and a bit resinous.  This is not a refreshing amber ale.  This is a bit heavy, yet well balanced and very sessinonable barley-wine-light.  Im a sucker for that type of beer when it is well done.  Freshness probably has a lot to do with the enjoyment factor.  I had the beer a while ago just after it came out, it was vibrant and I could have session a six-pack.  5 A.M.  To you all 5am morning people.  Stop saying it, stop f**king saying it.  For beer-drinking people like me there is no such thing as Good morning!.

Pours a deep beautiful amber into the glass with a 2-finger cotton candy head that reduces, leaving thick, pocked lacing.  The nose is of cola, biscuits and floral notes.  Flavors are dry, of cola, bread, light flour, caramel and finishing crisply, with a clean, dry bitter back.  The balance is superb, the mouthfeel smooth, and the palate is clean.  A lightly lingering bitter makes for a great session brew, and a very nice amber.
UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011 Dark amber beer with good head.Aroma,citrus hops,caramel ,cherry,.Taste hoppy bitter,light sweet,some caramel,some vegetables,flower,oregano.I would prefer if it were more sour.
Eh....Not really sure what to say about this. I didnt get much of anything out of it.
In bottiglia al Pub del Duca di Genova Nervi; mi è piaciuta.. una leggera birra ambrata con poco amaro e molto aroma di luppolo

had at beer Bistro Brewdog diner. pours a nice amber color, frothy beige foam. nose is malty with a good hop dose. Flavor is biscuit and sweet malt with a good bit of hops but super balanced.. could make this an every day beer

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with some reddish notes, head is small and off white/beige. Aroma is of grapefruit, caramel malts, juciy hops and resin. Flavor is of grapefruit, resinous and earthy hops, caramel and some slightly bready notes. Body is light to medium with a slightly dry and watery mouthfeel. Unfortunately this one tastes as if it has been sitting in my fridge a bit too long. But other than that it is a solid Amber Ale, that taste somewhat IPAish.

Cask conditioned at Moreton in Marsh Beer Fest 10. Dark amber with white head. An amazing beer in cask, good depth of body with a slightly caramel maltiness, then a whole gamut of hops bursting in from all angles, then ending in an orange fruitiness. Loved it,

Bottle at Galaxy Hut. Amber with an off-white head. Nose is biscuity, toffee malts, some hops, but not overpowering. Mouth is flavoursome with biscuity and bready taste from the malts, balanced by a woodland hop taste. Enjoyable.
Strange mix of IPA and red/amber ale. Smells great, first brewdog beer Ive had, cant wait for their others.

Bottle. Small head , red coppery color and sparkling. Fruity hop aroma with hints of lyche. Malty taste with mildly bitter hoppy aftertaste, not as bitter as I expect from Brewdog. Medium body. Good, but not that special. Good for beerdrinkers who have not tasted Brewdog yet.

Bottle at the World Beer Festival - Richmond on 06/12/2010. Clear amber body with a medium creamy off-white head. Sweet floral hop aroma. Sweet floral and citrus hop flavor with a caramel background. Medium full body with moderate carbonation.

Draught at Novare Res in Portland, Maine.  Pours hazy amber with a thick tan head. Nose is earthy and spicy hops, sweet caramel and crystal malt in the background.  Flavor is hoppy, but and kinda meh.  A nice session beer, I guess but not a whole lot going on.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber color with a medium white creamy head. The aroma is nice PNW hops and caramel- very good. The flavor is smooth; sweet hops, caramel, light pine and bitterness. Very nice. Dry somewhat.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful clear, golden amber with a big, fluffy beige head. Good lacing. Malty, pine hop aroma with a touch of candy sweetness. Pretty nice. Sweetish malty and pine hop flavour. A bit tart. Faint plastic notes, but not so much that it interferes with the experience. Dry, bitter liquorice finish with a lingering grassy note. Overall pretty nice, but the bitterness feels kind of fresh (in a bad way) for lack of a better word. Otherwise it would had scored higher overall. 10.09.10.

9/2/10 notes:  tap, in LA.  Color is copper with nice lacing.  Aroma is biscuit, toffee, minerals and cut grass.  Flavor jumps out with caramel and a good lightening hop touch.  Lots of toasted toffee, brown bread, and earthy notes through the middle.  Finishes with moderate bitterness and length.  Very enjoyable, though the serving I had probably wasnt the freshest.
Pours dark copper with a rich creamy off-white head and a citrus aroma. There is a tasty but subtle crystal malt base with massive hop bitterness. Lots of pine and grapefruit taste.

Bottle at Pivovarsky Klub, Prague. Nice amber beer with a beige/yellowish lasting creamy head. Floral fruity aroma, grassy, pine needles, milky notes and some alcohol in a good way. Some tropical fruits. Hoppy floral flavor, grassy, some fruit, metallic and with perfume notes. Long bitter finish.
Bottle a amber colored beer with a white/beige head aroma malts spices some fruits and hops taste malts spices some fruits and a bitter hop finish
From a bottle poured a dark amber color with a large fluffy head.  Bitter hoppy flavor with a quick finish.

Bottle.

Head is initially large, frothy, rocky, light brown, mostly lasting.
Body is dark amber.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain, cookie), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin), moderately yeasty (dough), with a note of sour apple.

Flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation.

Surprisingly disappointing, other than the appearance.  Usually this brewery does ok with the more modest ales, but this one has a lot of raw vitamin B yeast stink in the nose and the other aromatic components are just kinda ordinary and clunky.  Worse, the mouth experience is remarkably sour, like fruit juice gone bad.  Quite likely infected (at least I hope so).
bottle. great fruity aroma, amber color and great head. dry bitter taste with long palate.

bottle (best before Jan 19, 2011) - Pours amber with a huge, billowy off-white head.  The aroma is of citrus accented hops and caramel malt.  The flavor has heavily hopped bitterness with the malts taking a back seat.  It struck me as a touch watery and the hops could be a little more crisp.  Its enjoyable though.

330ml bottle. Pours a hazy red-amber, with a smooth off-white head, which lasts and lasts, leaving excellent lacing. In terms of looks, it really is hard to get any better than this beer. The aroma is not quite at that level, yet it is still very attractive, with strong pine and citrus notes from the hops, and the merest hint of nutty malt. This vanishes as one tastes the beer, however, as there is almost no detectable malt in the flavour; its a veritable hop-monster. Initial citrus hops dominate, with strong pine notes coming into play later. The palate, however, is perhaps ever so slightly too bitter. It is very interesting to see a darker ale such as this with such a hop focus, rather than being malt-driven. There are some quite interesting hops varieties in here too, with the Simcoe being particularly noticeable in the initial taste. For one such as myself, who enjoys a thoroughly hoppy beer, this is excellent, yet I can see that it is not the most approachable beer out there, and that it could potentially be a bit much for some.

12oz bottle -

Aroma - bright hop aroma, extremely floral, slightly spicy, guava, persimmon, hint of chocolate....brilliant.

Appearance - deep mahogany/root-beer brown body, clear with a giant 3" fluffy light tan head.  Great lacing. Perfect

Taste - extremely fruity with a fantastic hop spice bite that reminds me of caraway seeds.  Nutty, slight chocolate notes.

Palate - medium bodied, has a slight numbing effect on the tip of my tongue, medium carbonation, medium bitter finish

Overall - might just be the best Amber/red ale Ive had to date.  Incredibly priced, this could be a drinker for the next 2-3 months.
11.2oz bottle. Poured a deep amberish color with a large sized off white head. Aromas of grains, toasty, and some caramel. Tastes of caramel, toasty, and some citrus.

Appearance:  pretty--amber with dark brown notes and a decent head.  Aroma:  pine and grapefruit; lots of hops.  Taste:  bitter hops and pine.  Finish:  bitter, sour and dry.  Notes:  Ugh.  Like drinking metallic pine-sol.  I know everyone worships this brewery, but this does not seem to be an amber ale.  This is way more on the hoppy side, so more appropriate as an IPA.

This is a very impressive looking deep clear amber brew with a thick frothy tan head. Aroma of floral hops. Flavor is well hopped but also nicely balanced. Dry hopping is very evident. Finish is remarkable clean for all the hoppiness. Very nicely done!

clear dark amber, large lasting smooth offwhite head. 4 nice mild but quite hoppy aroma, pine,malts,red fruity,faint exotic fruity. 7 flavor is pine, grapefruit peel bitterness, malts. Lots of flavor considering the alc % 7

A clear amber colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of hopbitter with citrus and spices. The taste of sweet fruits. There are several hops with a nice bitterness. The aftertaste is a little sweet with bitter.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2010 33cl bottle: Chestnut colour with a slightly off-white head. Hoppy aroma, I mean much hoppier than some lesser IPAs. Dry citrussy and tropical with a nice depth added by the dark malts. Plenty of piney hoppiness, just a rich and juicy flavour with a medium-light mouthfeel and a little sweetness. Great and sessionable beer, BrewDog has yet to disappoint me. Really the only thing I didnt like was the slight metallic note in the flavour.

On Tap. Light Amber with bright citrus and deep herbal hops. When I say deep, I mean it. In the nose and the taste. It still manages to be very approachable and moderate. Not nearly as robust as would expect from the nose. A bit of malty, but very hoppy.

Deep amber colour with persistent cream coloured foam. Delightfully exotic nose; passionfruit, guava, honeysuckle and mango. Bitter, clean, coppery palate overwhelms the fruit offered by the palate. Coppery, bitter finish, which lets the fruit return, but for mine, not enough to overcome the excessively bitter copper characteristics.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2014 Pours amber with a white head. The Aroma has lots of pine, hops, lime and some citrus. Taste has those same notes with some more tropical notes added and a small amount of malts. Medium carbonation and a rather dry mouthfeel.

12oz bottle poured into a Shaker at 42°.  Color is a deep clear amber with light carbonation and a nice soft head.  Aroma of fresh hops and sweet roasted malts.  It has a lighter medium body that has a crisp almost sharp mouth feel.  Flavor comes on with raw grain, some hops and a strong bitterness.  After taste is dry with more bitterness.  Overall Im disappointed, the other brews I had from these guys where great, but this one is just rough.

Pours an amber burnt orange with a nice 1 finger head that disappeared after a bit and left some nice lacing going down.

Smells very nice-exactly what youd expect of an American Amber. Strong, but not off-putting, nice hops notes with a bit of maltiness and biscuit too. Looking forward to tasting this.

First sip goes down very well and picks up right where the smell takes off. Hoppy, citrusy, a bit malty, and with the bread/biscuit notes to back it all up. Very nice indeed.

Goes down smooth and balanced. Full of taste, but not heavy and feels good on the tongue/throat.

With a nice balanced ABV of 5% I think that I could drink this all day long. It may not be for some people, but if I could get my hands on this more often Id drink it regularly. Id compare this highly to some of the best American Ambers Ive tried.

Amber ale? really? this brew is hop stupid! more hoppy than any IPA ive ever had. It tasted like drinking liquid spruce and herbs and nothing else. If you love hops, youll love this beer. Simple as that.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Amber sweetish beer with a shitload of grassy hops. Not bad but too one dimensional in my opinion. Only few other flavours are somewhere underneath.

One of BrewDogs lower alcohol offerings. Pours dark brown with a thick bubbley head. Smell is citrus pine hops. Spruce. Strong and American in the nose. Taste is similar sharp pine, grassy hops but with a thick, aley, malty backing. Meaty, bitter with a tasty finish. Good Carbonation. very drinkable.

Bottle from Frank Smiths.  Pours clear deep coppery ruby with 3 finger off white head.  Nose is heavy Simcoe and Sauvin hops, floral, funky, feety, and caramel malty.  Tastes caramel malty, with a huge hop IBU presence, and a nice balance.  The palate is medium, not too hefty or complex, but this one makes no bones that it is all about the hops, and I can appreciate that.  This is one of those beers that seems like it is much higher ABV than 5%.

Poured from 12 ounce bottle into pint glass.  Formed a thick creamy beige head that dissipated slowly and left ample lacing.  The body is smooth and creamy.  Color is dark amber and a little hazy.  I was surprised by the aroma-it was very bright with hints of citrus, herbs and grass.  The flavor is slightly sweet and bitter, with hints of caramel, butterscotch and oak that have a mild resemblance of bourbon.

Poured amber with small white head. Aroma of dark fruits and hops. Medium bodied. Notes of dark fruits and candy overpowered by the extreme hoppiness. This quite annoyed me as I wasnt expecting this burst of bitter hops from an amber ale, nor was it strong enough to get away with it. Not one of BrewDogs better offerings.
Amber with an off white head.  Fairly hoppy, light caramel background- pretty one sided brew but pretty drinkable stuff, had this been brewed 6 years ago it would have been a hit.

from Amstein - pretty clear dark amber colour under a persistent beige head; superb lacework; a solid hoppy aroma with notes of quince marmalade, peach and cream; medium-bodied and with some astringency, moderate carbonation and very bitter; a long astringent bitterness with lot of hoppy fruity tones in the aftertaste

Its beautiful orange-red with a lasting, creamy head. The aroma is fruity and hoppy with notes of citrus and caramel. The moderately sweet flavour has notes of citrus, fruit, hints of spruce, caramel and the finish is slightly dry and bitter.

Clear amber pour with a huge off white froth that lasts nicely. The aroma bursts with a variety of hop incarnations, including citrus, herbal, floral, grassy, resinous and citrus notes. The malt character is dominant in the caramel and bread department, showing minor hints of oxidation and muddling. The flavor holds nutty caramel malt with bready biscuit notes and resinous bittering hops. Some tropical juicy fruit and citrus also makes an appearance. The hop character is certainly nothing like the aroma would suggest, but its pretty tasty. The palate is medium bodied for the style with low effervescence and an acidic, resinous finish. A hop forward Brew Dog brew that is actually tasty...nice.

Hands down the best ESB I have ever had, the 5 A.M. Saint could pass as a Red Ale or an IPA. A medium golden brown body and dissolving yellowish head houses an actual "premium" bitter taste. The brew is composed of a hop heavy flavor that is supported by a respectable amount of caramel malts. After finishing my "iconoclastic" bottle, I could only ask myself why I didnt get more. This is not a beer to pass up on if given the chance to purchase!

12 oz bottle shared with Scott at the GL.  Pours a coppery amber with a medium sized cream colored head.  Aroma of faint simcoe hops, bread dough, malt and fruit.  Taste is much the same as the aroma.

330ml bottle from Bacchanalia, Cambridge -  Batch #40  A copper pour with a billowing cream head that rapidly falls back; rich toffee aroma; oily in texture; sweet caramel flavour with some burnt toast ; and then a mouthful of hops, not overpowering, but well-balanced, fresh and grassy. Very moreish.
good head, nice carb, quite broad feel, burned malt and bittersweet hops on the nose, taste is sour dough and bitter in the end
UPDATED: MAR 26, 2011 Lovely distinctive aroma, grass, floral, and has a full bodied palate. Nice amber colour. Definitely worth a try!

330ml bottle. Pours well in the glass with a rich thick light tan foam head. Body is mahoganey teak in colourand looks solid. Sharp passionfruit aromas come through mixed with other fruit. Smooth in the mouth with a big long lasting aftertaste. One to sit on for a while.

A bit dark with a nice offwhite head
Fruti smell, and tast of a bit grape and caramell.
A nice beer, like brewdog more and more

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho. this might be the best brewdog beer, and the best red ale i have had. its simple, but delicious, drinkable, but rich. simple beers like this get overlooked, but they shouldnt . really a fantastic beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy grapefruit aroma with some hints of caramel. Sweetish malty hoppy flavor. Has a sweetish malty hoppy finish wit some hints of caramel.

Tap at Ginger Man.  Pale amber pour with a sticky white head.  The nose is fairly grassy with a touch of light orange marmalade and pine resin character.  Lightly fruity with a bit of slick sweetness on the back.  There is a butter/butterscotch character that I could definitely do without.  I want to like this beer, but I just dont.

Medium sized offwhite head, good retention and a lasting lace. Clear amber in color. Caramel greets you in the aroma along with citrusy, fruits. Body is lightly medium, lightly acidic, lightly grainy. Nice earthyness along with the caramel and citrus flavors, piney, resiny and a bit chewy. Dry, fruity bitter finish. A toughy. Bottle procured @statelineliquors.

12oz bottle at redlight redlight.  Amber pour with a thin tan head.  Muted sweet malt aroma.  Taste of hops, grapefruit, more hops, earthy, caramel and citrus peel.  Finishes up bready, bitter and dry.

On tap at City Beer in SF.

Great appearance: pours a deep translucent reddish-amber color with a fairly thick off-white head and good lacing.

Aroma is slightly faded citrusy hops, earthy notes, and caramel malt.  A little restrained, but pleasant.

Great flavor.  This is somewhere between an American Amber Ale and an ESB if you ask me.  Caramel malt is pretty big, with herbal notes, earth, and citrusy (orange/tangerine) hops.

Medium-bodied and smooth on the palate with a good carbonation level.

This beer is somewhat of the antithesis of BrewDog Tokyo*.  Instead of being a hot mess, its restrained, balanced, and well-crafted.  Drinkability is good.  I approve.

Pours a coppery red body with a decent white head. Smell is citric strawberry aromas with grassy hops and hints of caramel. Taste follows up: lost of bitter hops as always with BrewDog, as well as some fruitiness in the hop profile. Toffee and vague notions of licorice as well. Bitter finish. Nice stuff.
on tap.ambrata, al naso sfumature di caramello e spezie. al gusto molti i sentori di resina, caramello e agrumi.finale decisamente luppolato e secco.

Loving it on draught, pours out a deep amber, nose is nice & intense, loads of pine resin with some spices, a citrus blast mainly grapefruit, a fruity undertone & some sweetness in there perhaps a christmas pud lurking about.   Nice & rounded palate, biscuit caramel, some lovely light maltiness, burnt orange peel  & that lovely resinous backbone.  The finish is long with lots of bittering hops but tempered nicely by the richness of the beer.  Top stuff

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of hops, pine, malt, and a hint of fruit.  Poured amber in color with a huge, dense, fluffy, beige head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of malt, caramel, pine, slight citrus, light resin, and hops.  Medium body.  Slightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Medium sweet, light to medium bitter, malt, caramel, pine, resin, and hop finish is a tad dry.  A little too malty and sweet IMO.

A bottle at "The Rake" in the Boro Market (God Bless It) . Challenging, nice head, nice colour, smooth "amber" hidden under an almost synthetic hop note, resin and plastic, a fetish beer. It was my first of the day (11:30am) and maybe my palate wasnt keyed in to it. Nice job though. More please Miss Whiplash ;-)

Sampled at DØE Beerfestival 2010, TAP1. Pours a clear and dark amber beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is hops. The flavor is hops with peach and citrus. The palate is bitterness. Overall an average beer.

Bottled sample at the World Beer Festival Richmond, 6/12/10. Pours a hazy brownish copper color with a thin head. Decent head retention and lacing. Huge citrus hop aroma with some tropical and resiny notes. The taste is bitter citrus and resin hops with some toffee notes. Medium bodied.

Rich earthy hops on the nose, spicy with heavy malt aromas as well.  Pours a reddish amber with thick off white head. Massively hoppy, loads of hop flavor, piney and earthy with hints of grapefruit peel.  Great hoppy session beer.
Dark amber with an off white head. A little malt in the aroma and a lot of piney hops that impart a salty seaside tang that Im not too keen on. Grapefruit taste and a sharp bitter finish. Hmm...
Bottle. Huge head with excellent duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich hops, flowers, malt and caramel. Nice and bitter finish.
Dark amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of malt, bread, hops, grapefruits and weak toffee. A flavor of caramel, hops, bread, malt and grapefruti.

This bottled brew marked batch 10 best before 03/03/2011 from the brewery poured a large sized head of foamy with a frothy top tan colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a softly carbonated transparent copper brown colored body and a thick foamy lacing. The nice aroma was nutty and brown malt. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish with a biting hoppy bitter  aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of nutty and brown malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

bottle from Bierzwerg. Clear deep golden colour, mid-sized head. Citrusy hops in the nose. Light, shy malty base with a good amount of good English hops that adda citrusy character and a touch of grass.

330ml bottle.  Nose on this beer was spot on, bucket loads of hops, resin and grass, it smelt like a weaker hardcore and I was expecting that on the taste but I was disapointed.  Very watery taste and thin mouthfeel.  Im not sure whether I had a bad bottle as its the first Brewdog I didnt like.  Will try again, but not in a hurry.

honestly one of the most balanced brews Ive had from these guys, even though this one too is still decidedly slanted well toward the hops. a big bitter billed as an amber that could readily pass for a "red ale." nice garnet colour with a fairly big head that foreshadows some serious fizz, giving the palate a bit of a bite. very effervescent. hops on the nose, evergreen and flowery being the most dominant with some dry citrus notes present too. enough of a malt presence to notice even under the hops, with some toasty, biscuity notes on the palate, just a hint of caramel sweetness that almost gets buried under the fizz.

This is a good looking beer.  Its a deep, translucent amber with a foamy, ecru head.  Lots of lacing.  Im a fan of the BrewDog labels, too, so thats a nice a bonus.  This is a nicely hoppy beer with good British malt flavor.  The aroma from the hops is floral, pine and citric, in that order, while the malt contributes lots of biscuity, doughy caramel goodness.  The malt aroma holds its own against the hops with a luxurious depth, differentiating the beer from most American ambers and such.  This is a hoppy ESB.  The flavor is rich and full.  Theres a lot of good British beer flavor.  Its not quite as bursting at the seams of its size but close.  Mouthfeel is a tad slick.  The aftertaste is hoppy and bitter.  Its a very good beer, easily one of my favorites from BrewDog.

12oz bottle, purchased at City Beer. Pours a deep, generally clear, ruby-orange color; significant light-tan head with good retention and lacing. The English malt character shows through pretty clearly in the aroma (biscuity, some caramel) alongside grassy, piney, and citrusy hop character; nicely complex hop aroma, and definitely comes across on the English side of the equation despite the American-style hopping; that caramel note and Marris Otter maltiness are quite persistent; seems nicely dry from the nose. Medium to medium-light body; average levels of carbonation; very light creaminess, with no astringency or alcohol; the mouthfeel as a whole is pretty close to perfect, and I could see myself sessioning a whole lot of this under other circumstances; the caramel and biscuity malt core is well-expressed and nicely dry, while the hopping is just excellent and tempered: citrus, pine, and floral notes, and theres the grassiness from the dry hopping evident throughout; lightly bitter overall, and just hugely drinkable. Beautifully done, and a great rendition of a style thats just so damn difficult to find fresh in the States these days. Dig it. Medium, toasty finish, showing hints of marshmallow (that soft, malty core), biscuity notes, and a lingering citrus / grassy hop bitterness.

Bottled. Amber with thin head. Aroma is big and beautiful hop fruityness of grapefruit and other fruits and background caramels. Flavor also brings caramel. Beer is dry hopped wild and has a ton of hop flavors (more of that fruit all over mostly a sweeter grapefruit) but is so damn dry throughout its hard to say much else. Still great.

@CBC RareBeer Touron tap-pours a retaining thin light tan head that laces and amber color.  Aroma is citrus rind, secondary medium malt.  Taste is citrus-orange rind/resin, secondary medium malt-peat/caramel.  Good effervescence.
WBF Richmond: Piney smell, with bark undertones, good strength. Clear copper, thick yellow head. Somewhat resinous pine then caramel . More piney than I prefer but a solid beer.

Golden-brown and clear. Has an off-white head, lasting. Aroma is heavy hopped, citrus, rubber, passion-fruit, faint malty background. Flavor heavy hoppy, bitter, Moderate soft sweetness. Dry, creamy texture.
very hoppy aroma,brown golden, clear, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish,

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2011 Bottle, 33cl. Nice deep amber pour with a large off-white head. (dont pout it too hard, its very lively). The aroma is packed with juicy hops containing grapes, lime pine needles, and the classic Nelson Sauvin touch, a fine balance of malt sweetness, bread crust and caramel. The taste has grape fruit, grapes, mango, a nice amount of bitterness and fruity hops. A great session.

First: this beer isnt shy on the froth.  With a large, airy off-white/light-brown head atop a glowy mahogany/ruby color, 5AM Saint doesnt look like your run of the mill "amber ale".  Its patchy, big-bubbled lacing makes for great glass decor.  This beer is almost more on the English end of things - adds a nice edge to a sweet, hoppy aroma.  Spicy almost.  Great nose.  Unique palate.  Thin, but not watery or alcoholic.  Very, very heavy on hops.  Bitter, green finish.  Again, not your everyday amber or ESB, even.  Warm in the mouth.  Great combo of hops... Im impressed.

Thank you Chris (darkguardian) for the bonus!  330mL, best before 19-04-11 (batch 40).  Clear copper with a 1 1/2 finger creamy beige head, good retention.  Toasted malts with some earthy toffee dominate with some light chocolate and black pepper notes following.  Hops consist of light mango and citrus, light grass, and just smells of overbitteredness.  Flavor is grassy and earthy, some peppery notes again with too much bittering hops.  There is some of the toffee again and plenty of the dirty earthy notes (redundant).  Burps unsalted saltine crackers.  Once it warmed the hops turned a little fruitier, but nothing could make up for the finish.  Dirty dirty bitterness peaking at a 7, dry.  Medium to high carbonation with a medium body.  I think theyre mistaking bucketloads of dry hops with too much friggin bittering hops to make this not very drinkable and a waste of hops/$.  I was excited to try this, but no.  Just no.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Light malty and heavy hoppy aroma. Pine and perfumed notes. More IPA like than ESB-like. Heavy bitter almost harsh IPA flavor. Long heavy bitter finish. Creamy palate. Excellent but not style true.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2010 Pours a deep, deep amber with a tan, extremely lush head.  The hop notes hit you before your nose gets near the glass.  Once the foam settles, you can really get the pine, resin, and grassy citrus notes, along with a whiff of caramel maltiness.  Really great aroma.  Nice flavors, too.  Thinner mouthfeel, low to moderate carbonation, faintly sweet with a good balance of malt and hop character. The beer only finishes moderately bitter; clearly the hops are almost all aromatic.  Really smooth.  The bitter definitely starts to build up as you drink it though, and by the end of the 12oz I was glad to switch to something else.  Most certainly not sessionable, despite the low ABV.  Glad to have tried it, and its a solid beer, but Ill have trouble paying $3.70 a bottle for it, this gets dinged for the crazy price.

Bottle. Pours a dark orange with a finger of tan head. Aroma is quite like Alpha Dog, fruity, slightly resinous, with a fresh cut grass note, and a powdery chocolate feel to it. Smells amazing, tastes great. Sweet at first, before a generous bitter finish cleans it all up. Medium to light body, lively carbonated. This is a very drinkable, easy to like, no fancy tricks beer that you can drink all night yet still appreciate the complexity of.

Bottle. Pours a clear, dark amber colour with a large, frothy, off-white head. Aroma is predominantly dry and hoppy, much like an IPA, with flowers, pine, citrus, caramel and orange. The simcoe hops are standing out quite nicely. Taste is really like an IPA, very hoppy and floral with hints of citrus, lime and earth/pine. Initially very malty with caramel, thence quite bitter and hoppy on the finish. Medium body, lively carbonation, fairly long duration. Very fresh and soothing. It reminds me  of the Mikkeller Single Hop Simcoe which is very nice.

11.2oz bottle, fresh from grape & gourmet. pours a clear, ruby-copper, with a thick, creamy, off-white head leaving sheets of lace on the glass. aroma is excellent, the dry hopping really shows, with huge fruity and woodsy hop notes of grapefruit, orange peel, and peach skins with sprucy, pine resins, and wet grass backed by light, nutty (i really got pistachio shells from this), toasted malts and caramel cereal. flavor is delicious as well, more balanced than the aroma, with bitter pine needles, citrus fruits, and a touch of pineapple up front backed by toasted cereal grains, caramel malts, and more roasted nuts with a bitter, crisp, hoppy finish. palate is medium bodied and slightly dry on the palate with perfect carbonation making this one extremely sessionable. overall, a damn fine beer from the brewdog boys be it an ESB or an amber.

Thanks to 17thfloor for sharing this 12 oz bottle! Pours a nice copper amber color with a creamy long lasting light tan head. Aroma is very fresh hops citric and floral almost herbal, beautifully blended. Spicy and sweet toasted malts with just a hint of alcohol. Flavor starts sweet, a little fruity and/or cakey. Picks up a nice mellow hoppiness, again with the citric, orange a touch of mango. A modest bitterness in the finish balances the sweet but fades quickly after the swallow. Medium body and soft carbonation. Very nice, both complex and rich but I could see myself drinking a beer like this all night.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2015 Nice, amber-redish coloured substance with an off-white, lightly beige head. Head holds very good; Hoppy and fruity smell. Lots of hops. Some weird sweetness at the first taste, that makes place quicky for the sour-biterness. Hoppy, citrus and some spices. Taste is not bad, but not 100% my thing. Aftertaste is also hoppy-bitter, with some citrus inside.  Retasted from tap. Better then before for sure, had to add some points.
Orangy amber color with an off-white head.  Light malt aroma followed by a lightly husky malt/cereal flavor.  Smooth and easy drinking, a great session beer.
At wbf richmond.  Pours a clear amber.  Great earthy woodsy hop with burnt malty backbone.  Really nicely crafted.  Dryy lingering hop bite.

Bottle. Pretty copper pour with a tall, beige head. Strong hoppy and citrusy nose. Light caramel, hints of toffee and orange peel also. Taste is bitter hops, big citrus fruit, caramel, light toffee, sweet malt, and soft herbal hops. Body is medium with a strong, bubbly carbonation and a lingering bitterness. Ends with more bitter hops, citrus fruit, aspirin notes, light caramel and toffee, and soft herbal hops.

0,3l bottle, fantastic aroma from england hop- i love that, amber, clear, frothy, rocky head, white foam, brown foam, very bitter, light sweetness, medium body, slick feel, thick feel, average carbonation, long finish, bitter, second beer from brewdog...both awesome  I will emigrate to Scotland :)
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: KØ10. Mild hop aroma, NS? Thin mouthfeel. Clear dark amber colour. Small stable tan hea. OK hop flavour, caramel and hops.

Bottle from a bottleshop, RBESG Rome day 3. Clear dark amber to brown colour, light beige head. Aroma of piney hops, rather strong hoppy, caramel, light burnt notes. Flavour is malty sweet, caramel, light spicy, strong bitter hoppy finish. Medium bodied.

330ml bottle. Pours amber brown with a thick and long lasting head. The aroma consists of caramel, hay, resin, spruce, and a little earthiness. The taste has a moderate level of sweetness and medium bitterness.
Pours medium-dark, slightly hazy with a decent head.  Taste is punchy and broad, plenty of dark-fruits, plum and raisen, an oaky, resiny background with a good hoppy finish.  Really tasty, good.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2010 Deep amber ale with a white rocky head. Aroma: citrus (orange, grapefruit), sweet, hops. Very aggressive. Taste: Heavy bitter, light to medium sweet. 
Palate: Medium body, average carbonation, strong bitter finish and anstringent. Typical extreme "BrewDog trademark". Not for all, but i like.

Bottle poured a clear dark amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of carmel, fruittiness and light earthiness. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smooth finish. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and fruittiness with a smooth lightly bitter fruity finish.
Pours dark copper with a beige head. Aroma is malt, fruity notes and some hop. Flavour is malt, caramel, light bitter and flowery and citrus hop.
Clear amber with a small off-white head. Hoppy, citrus and candy aroma. Drinks sweet and pine bitter. Medium body Syrupy texture.  Sampler@Ølfestival København 2010.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2010 Bottle.  Okay, so BrewDog stuff doesnt always arrive in the State quite so fresh... this is very fresh!  Pours the most gorgeous clear glowing rich very red amber with a super sticky tall foamy fluffy frothy light beige head, perfect.  Aroma has a touch of tea, light caramel sweetness, loads of pine, very resinous, delicate but sharp and bright, spruce, tree sap, botanical.  Flavor at first is super sprucy and dry piney, pine needles, seemed a bit dry and vacant, then light delicate caramel, loads of pine needles, resinous, touch of honey in the finish, deliciously hoppy, medium strong bitterness.  Medium bodied, easy drinking, plenty of sharp sizzling carbonation, just a hint of stickiness, well attenuated.  Excellent! (on my 3rd out of the 4pck, soooo good and Im appreciating it even more now!  )

Bottle. Pours dark amber with a lasting beige head. A beastly aroma of hop goodness - tropical fruits, pine tree and perfume notes. Flavour is caramel malt, hint of chocolate, tropical fruits and pine hops. Medium bodied. Great bitterness that leads to a dry hoppy finish. A winner!

Had on tap at Haven Gastropub.  Pours amber with good amount of head (about 1 finger).  Aroma is malts, with heavy hop citrus (grapefruit and lemons).  Taste is the same - heavy on the hops for an amber, lots of underlying malt flavorings.  Finishes bitter, seemed like a fairly standard hoppy amber.  Nothing special, but probably getting high ratings from the BrewDog name.

Bottle at Beer Engine into shaker.  Definitely get the hops in here in both aroma and flavor with a nice ruby/amber pour, and a little bit of something like smoke but also a nicer touch of that bandaid taste you can get in bad scotch ales which gives it a nice dry, bitter finish.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Fireworks 
It pours a nice amber color with a sizeable foamy, white head.  The nose is hop forward with notes of herbals and a bit of pine.  Caramel malt vies with resinous and acrid hops for control of your palate.  The body is light to medium leading to a slightly dry, lingering bitter finish.  A decent session amber with a nice hop kick and that distinct BrewDog bite.

Bottle. Pours a dark orange/red color with a big foamy egg shell head. Nose is quite hoppy up front with floral and citrusy notes. Palate is medium bodied with a stickiness, nice bitterness in the finish. Flavor is floral hop notes, amber malt notes, light caramel. pretty refreshing

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2010 Not a big fan of brewdog, but I know a good hoppy beer when I taste it. Lots of pineapple and mango on the nose in the mouth it is lovely, smooth and hoppy almost reminding me of some of san diegos best. A bit more body to offset the hopping regime would shoot this in to the stratesphere. Well done BD. Great price (at some establishments) too.

Draught. Dark amber-brown looking colour. Hoppy fruity citrus sweetish malty aroma. God mouthfeel. Flavour is fresh with fruity bitter hops, some pine and citrus, sweet, moderate maltiness. Bitter hoppy finish.

11.2 ounce bottle, Batch 483, best before January 19, 2011.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours a reddish/amber color with about an inch off-white head.  The bottle was a bit of a gusher when I opened it, but it didnt take long to settle down and make a decent pour.  Head retention and lacing are both very good.  Aroma is nice and hoppy, the brew smells mostly like pine and citrusy (grapefruit, tropical fruit) hops, along with a bit of caramel malt.  Taste is the same as the aroma, but the citrusy hops come out stronger in the taste compared to the other flavors.  Theres also a good lingering bitter hoppy finish.  Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, its a bit slick and has good carbonation.  Drinkability is pretty good, this is quite a sessionable brew!  This is a good overall brew, its one of the best amber ales Ive had in a while.

Cask at the Cask, Pub and Kitchen, Pimlico. Pours reddish-brown with a white head. Great nose. Full of blackcurrants, red berries, pine, fresh bread. Juicy, fruity flavours of blackcurrants, black cherries, malts, raspberries, some caramel. Dry, fruity finish. Very good.

Bottle bought at Kegs and Barrels on 15th in Plano TX and poured into a pint glass.

A dark brown with a slight red hue with a tall light tan head that has good retention.  The smell is fascinating with fresh cut grass, rye, pine and citrus.  The taste is particularly piney with hints of leather and nut with grapefruit on the finish.  very interesting.  Certainly not what i expected.

(bottle, 33cl) Clear, ruby colour with a medium-sized and slightly beige foamy head. Rich piney, fruity (red berries, lemon) and flowery hoppy aroma with light toasty malt in the background. Moderately bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a smooth carbonation. Dry and complex malty taste with liquorice and toasty elements and a cornucopia of hop flavours upfront; dry and complex hoppy finish with a mildly malty background and an almost never ending hoppy, piney aftertaste. Great, because it is complex AND sessionable. 20.V.10
Pours a reddish brown color with aromas of coffee and hops.  Taste is bitter throughout, closer to an IPA style taste.  Overall not my favorite but glad I tried this one.

The beer pours a reddish-brown color with a khaki head. The aroma is toffee and bready malt with some orange hops. There is also some chocolate malt and pine hop notes in the aroma. The flavor is heavy on the toffee and caramel malts with pine added in. The chocolate malts are faint but are present in the flavor as well. Very little hop bitterness but a good amount of hop flavor. Thin-medium mouthfeel and medium-high carbonation.

Floral aroma, some honey smell.

 Fresh, but rather bitter.

 Quite nice.

 Sampled at ølfestival.
Bottle at Beer Temple, Amsterdam. Ruby red colour with a small head. Grapefruity hoppiness. Some caramel to balance the intense citrussy bitterness. Single-minded, but delivers quite a punch.

Ruby red in colour with a tight green tinged tan head. Big floral hop hit. Just stinks of hops, bigtime. Nice. Has a nettle kind of sting on the palate with a lengthy dry resinous hop finish.  Humurous reading label. Go again for shure on this one.

This is really good. The pour is dark amber, clear with a big condensed head that laces and stays around to the last gulp. Malty bread like aroma with some caramel in there. The flavor is very malty with a nice earthiness to it. It ends bitter. Finishes dry with a very nice after taste.

DØE Festival, Valby, DK.
Tap, 060510.
Amber with white head. Aroma of citrus, passionfruit and flora. Flavor is malt with spices.

Draft at DBF 2010.
Amber with an off-white head. Aroma moderate malty (caramel), heavy hoppy (peach). Flavor moderate sweet, moderate to heavy bitter. Medium body.

Rating #7 from danish beer festival 2010
Clear brown look with no head. Nice grabe aroma with some some pine aswell. Also has a little wierd molten note. Clean flavor with a light malty sweetness and a medium bitterness.

$3 / 12oz bottle - Not bad for a style of beer Im not thrilled about.  Obviously bitter, but the IBUs are not that high at all--not sure how this works.  This brew pours a beautiful amber color and long-lasting creamy head on top.  Fairly carbonated.  Basically, I have to acknowledge how well this is brewed, but not a huge fan of style.  The bitterness is starting to grow on me though.

Bottle. Forgot wherefrom. Pours copper/amber with a 3 finger foamy beige head. The aroma is full of cat pee and lots of other hoppy things. Medium plus body with foamy/coarse carbonation. Flavor is something like chocolatey malt with a lot of floral and citrus hop. This is so hoppy.  It finishes very, very hoppy. Its so hoppy its almost having a burnt rubber note. Its hoppy. Its very hoppy. Repeat that any number of times.

100ml from tap. Clear, dark amber with a lacing layer. Fresh smell of citrus fruits. Succulent taste of fruits followed by the flavour of late fruits and herbal hops. Dry, rounded hop bitter finish. Sappy palate. A promising start to my happy drinking days at Ølfestivalen in Copenhagen, 06.05.2010.

12oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear deep amber with a long lasting lace inducing white head. Nose is tons of resin and hop with a very fruity note of peach or apricot. Flavor hits you with bitterness up front and follows with a ton of piney hop flavor and finishes with a huge dose of rich caramel and toasty bread. Bitterness lingers with a hint of caramel. This is about as good as it gets for the style. Fantastic.

Bottle. Pours clearish red/brown with a big offwhite head and good lace. Smells big and metallic, slightly malty and sweet with a hint of red fruit hoppiness. Tastes lightly malty and sweet with a good bit of red fruit hops, bitter and slightly spicy. Some metallic flavors as well. Tastes ok. Watery, thin body and good carbonation.

Pours dark amber into an English pint. Fluffy off-white head with excellent retention recedes leaving slight sheets. Dark caramel and resin aromas. Astringent with upfront sweet roasted nuts turning to a dark resin and pine finish.

(33cl bottle, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a clear amber body with a moderate cream head.  Aroma of herbs, grass, caramel, and light citrus.  Flavor of grass, herbs, and caramel with a bitter finish.

Bottle Clear amber ale with copper highlights and a small, creamy, white head. Resiny, earthy hops are standouts in the aroma tailed - from a good distance - by dashes of buttery toffee and caramel. Medium-bodied with lively carbonation. The flavor is of toffee sweetness and earthy, piney bitterness overlying subtle acidity. Finishes crisp and lightly bitter. Bottle courtesy of darkguardian!

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James and Tony. Pours amber brown with a small, off-white head. Aroma of sweet fruits, malts, banana, bitter hops, and pine. Medium to full bodied with a slightly sticky, bitter palate. Finishes cleanly, with a lingering bitterness on the tongue. I have primarily disliked every bitter I have every tried before this. Definitely a pleasant surprise.

Tap. Clear amber with a creamy longlasting light tan head. The aroma is peach, caramel, fruit, light pine and citrus. The flavour is pine, bitter hops, citrus and peach. Medium bodied. Great session beer!
Sample. Dark amber body with small off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel and lots of hops.

Bottle split with Pat and Tony.  Pours a golden honey amber body. Aroma is pine hop and sweet candy malt. Also some fruit. Mouthfeel is smooth and medium to thin. Taste is smooth clean hop flavor... pine and grass.
Had with james and pat. Pour is clear brown. Aroma isnt too pungent. Hints of banana starburst. Flavor is some vanilla, bits of plaster.

330ml bottle red brown coloured pour decent head light biege in colour aromas are fruit floral touch caramelmalt earthyness bubblegum really good stuff flavour citrus grapefryut some passionfruit a bitter citric taste caramel good fizz on the palate apricot taste finish is very hoppy fruit taste good bitter sweet malt aftertaste

07-MAY-2010, @Beerfestival.dk.
No idea what type this was before tasting. - still not sure:)
Very bitter from hops, but the malts dominate though.
If the style is really a bitter, I need to try more of those.

330mL bottle.  Pours clear dark amber with a rocky, persistent tan head.  The hops dominate the aroma, floral, citrus, pine, honey, some fruit, with a little caramel in the back.  The flavour is a little more malty with some toastiness, loads of hops, medium sweetness and bitterness.  Light bodied, below average carbonation, hoppy and slightly astringent finish.

Bottle: Pours a transparent deep copper amber with a spotty-lacing froth of light tan head.  Has a nice, fresh assertive piny hoppy nose with nice underlying toasty caramel malty notes.  Starts with pretty good fullness for the style with light caramel sweetness well-balanced with fresh floral resiny hop bitterness and flavor before a crisp, smooth finish.  Very drinkable and true to style.

pours reddish brown with medium white head. aroma is big and hoppy with a nice light sweetness coming through. taste is bitter and resiny with floral hops. bitter throughout and has light peaks of sweet malts coming in. aftertaste is long lasting and quite pleasant with sweet and bitter together.

12oz glass on tap at Churchkey DC.  Pours a reddish, basically transparent amber with a frothy, white head.  Nice lacing.  Nice hoppy aroma, light caramel, whole grain bread, light candy, C hops.  Flavor was well balanced and not at all aggressive, citrus, bread, zingy spices.  Medium bodied finish.  For a beer that says its only 25 IBUs, this had a lot of solid hop flavor and aroma while still being approachable.

Bottle. Clear copery amber pour with a creamy beige head that lasts a while and leaves plenty of lacing. Aroma is very hoppy and fruity with notes of passionfruit, orange, grapefruit, peach, apricot and toffee. Flavour has a stronger malt backbone, with more caramel and toffee notes, but otherwise pretty much mirrors the aroma. Mouthfeel is light without being too thin, with moderate carbonation and a long finish that starts out fruity and gradually becomes more bitter. Another great beer from Brewdog, kind of like a cross between an ESB and an IPA, thoroughly enjoyable, easygoing and very sessionable.
bottle from Cornelius @ train Edinburgh to Glasgow. Copper color, short head. Bit hoppy aroma, some malt. Good bitterness in taste. Decent stuff.

Good beer (understatement).  The bright and fresh hop aroma stays in your nose even when youre breathing out.  Resin and citrus, something chewy, the aroma is like the small amount of sodium in Dasani water that never slakes your thirst.  The flavor is even more hops, its like the roof of my mouth is doing some smelling too.  A bitter bite comes and goes very quickly then follows the beer down for a couple seconds while the hop vapors use the opportunity to float upwards and out the nose.  I need to get my hands on more of this and try more Brew Dog beer.  Yay beer!

Pours a clear, reddish amber with a creamy, dense, tan head. Excellent retention and lace. Aroma is hoppy, caramel, rye toast, fresh strawberries, candi sugar. Taste is spicy hops, rye bread, older/degrading hop cones.

Bottle 33cl. Pours a clear reddish amber, with a medium white head and an aroma of sweet and sour fruit, grassy hops and a touch of toffee. The taste is a bit malty with some toffee, synthetic sweetender, grassy hops and some herbs. a medium-long finish sums up this above-average bitter.
Amber fruit on palatte. Dark reddish color in glass. Thick head. Hoppy nose has slight hint of pumpernickel.

Bottle. Dark amber color. Lots of grapefruit, melon and oily hops in the somewhat perfumed aroma. Thinnish but very tasty. Melon, oily hops, grapefruit, hint of toffee. Just loved this very drinkable beer.

Pours dark amber/ruby with a large, lasting off-white head.
Nose shows loads of peach, passionfruit, orange blossom, lemon, green apples, etc, etc. Incredibly fruity. Later on pine, grapefruit and grassy notes become more prominent. Restrained clean malt underneath. This aroma was dangerously close to getting full marks.
Malt is more noticeable as a flavour, with nutty and caramel hints. More pin, grapefruit, peach and passionfruit are also present. Bitterness is quite prominent in a very green, hoppy finish of significant duration.
Carbonation is on the high side in my opinion, apart from that this was great.

Bottle. Need to re-rate this one, not sure how well I actually tasted it, because I have a cold. Pours a clear amber beer with a medium white head.   Citrus, orange peels, grapefruit, grass, vanilla(?). Taste is bitter with little sweetness.

(bottle) pours a clear ruby-amber colour with a dense frothy off-white head. aroma of passion fruit, lemons and pineapples, some mango and a touch of caramel. flavour is slightly grainy pale malts, light caramel, bubblegum and grass, surprisingly earthy and not so tropical, with a medium bitter finish. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.
33cl, new Scottish brew Anno 2009, from Slijterij van Bergen Eindhoven, complex bitter brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, clear, rocky head, good brew

Clear and bright reddy amber body with off-white head. Starting to like grapefruit, this shows it in the nose and the taste, some resin notes as well as some supporting caramel. Thought it finished a little cloying and heavy at first but didnt notice it later. Enjoyable!

Bottle, drinks more like an ipa amber hybrid.  Pours a mahogany body with a tan off white head.  Very hoppy, grassy, slick oily hop resinous tones, light citrus, grass, hemp, herbs, strong earth y floral hop tones.  Malty gram notes with a light mineral tone.  Hops stay with you in a grassy sort of fresh manner.  Awesome session ale.

Bottle. Poured clear copper color with an average to large frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy earthy hop aroma. Medium to full body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy spicy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. Solid drinkable beer.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2013 Cask conditioned	handpump	The Rake	Borough Market.  A red coloured beer with a loose whitish head.  A massive sharp hoppy aroma with grapefruit and hints of strawberry.  Strong grapefruit flavours.  Tons and tons of hops but so drinkable.  Sharp, very bitter and very nice.  I continue to be surprised at how good BrewDogs beers continue to be no matter what they try (except Storm).  Score 4Subsequent ratings scored 3.5, 3.6, 3.8, 3.8, 3.7, 3.6, 3.8, 3.7, 3.7, 3.7 and 3.7. Average becomes 3.7

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2010 Bottle 12C. Pours amber with a small beige head. Aroma is of lots of grapefruit and resin over some caramel. Theres some visible carbonation but mouthfeel is curiously flat. Taste is again mostly about hops - theyre quite bitey and the grapefruit is almost astringent. Theres some biscuit and dough just detectable, but the malt is pretty much overwhelmed. Way out of balance at least to my tastes, but the aromatics are fresh tasting and the bitterness - whilst more than the beer can take - is not so much to make it tiring to drink. [3.2]A much better bottle. Large beige head, much more alive mouthfeel, no particular astringency. Still disjointed and unbalanced (as above) but pretty tasty.

Bottle from Berts Bierhuis. Pours a brownish/orange beer with a good white head. Big overwhelming aroma which I really liked. Hints of spices, grapefruit and a lot of hops. Taste is also very hoppy with a decent aftertaste. Enjoyed every sip. Hops, hops & hops!

Pours dark reddish brown with a large off-white head.  Aroma is heavy on the grapefruit of all things, along with leaves, bell peppers, wheat, caramel, and plant store aromas.  Flavor is also a hop assault with astringent grapefruit, plants, dirt, ash, breadcrust, but really very little malt backbone.  Finishes tangy with grapefruit, wood, char, grass, and burnt toast.  Very bitter.  Mouthfeel is surprisingly fluffy and light, but the lack of malt doesnt do the beer any favors, for me at least.  Its interesting to have a light amber/ESB with this much dominant hop character, but damn!

Bottle. Pours a deep amber with rocky cream coloured head. Some lacing as it falls away. Heaps of dry hoping has left huge though slightly harsh resiny grassy hop aromas with some citrus (grapefruit and lemon) coming through., Not much in the way off malt to balance. Flavours are very bitter thanks to all the hops though there is slightly more malt sweetness to balance. Finish is extremely resiny. Mouthfeel is a tad thin. Good beer

Bottle from Beer Ritz, Leeds, drunk at home watching the Masters. Dark orange pour with a lingering off white head. Resinous hop aplenty in the nose with caramel malt and citrus notes. Flavour walked a similar path, fruity with some great hoppage in evidence. Lingering bitter finish . Really tasty stuff, could very happily drink a load of this.  Another top notch effort from BD.

33cl, best by 1/19/11.  Medium off-white head, nice lacing, atop crystal clear dark amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, orange, grape, some grapefruit. peach.  Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit, orange, some peach, light caramel.  Light-medium body, some resin, light chewiness, very drinkable.

Bottle.  Dark amber beer with a strongish head.  The aroma is very well hopped, and the flavour is also very well hopped with a smooth slightly yeasty finish.  Overall a very nice well hopped beer in the American style.

12 oz bottle bottle from OTM. Pours a nice deep amber with a small white head. The nose is sweet with floral hop nectar, some fruit characters too. Mild hop flavors, some crystallized caramel, bitterness, and a dry finish.

Bottle; glad this one was at a reasonable price.  Pour a rich auburnish color with a big frothy, off white head.  Aroma was absolutely delicious, especially for the style; sweet, fruity, caramel, flowers and citrus.  REally top notch nose.  Flavor was not as good, but that was admittedly a tall order.  More earthy, with some caramel, bread, citrus, and fruit.  On the whole, the nose was the star of the show.  Great stuff there.
Bottle at RBNAG-2009. Pale amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is peaches, grapefruit, malt, orange. Flavour is peaches, grapefruit, malt, orange. Medium body. Nice beer.

Pours crystal-clear dark amber-brown with a nice dense fluffy head and decent lacing. Aroma-honey, cereal, hops. Taste-immediate herbal notes followed by piney hops, earth, then biscuity malt. Finishes medium bodied, dry and herbal.
Pours amber with a beige head. Aroma of pine hops and caramel. Flavor is very much the same as well. Mouth feel is medium body with high carbonation. Overall, its not bad at all.

12oz bottle.  Crystal clear reddish brown with a creamy off white head that left some spotty lacing.  Tons of roasted malts with some bready notes.....faint hops.  Some grain and citrus qualities in the finish. I think the best Brewdog beer Ive tried to date....
Bottle obtained from the brewery.  Pours mahogoney coloured body with generous bubbly head bubble.  Some lace in glass.  Medium moutheel.  Taste is very much like a harvest ipa.

Clear reddish/brown pour.  Creamy, off white head. Lots of caramel malt and spicy hops in the nose.  Flavor is creamy and hoppy.  Nice spicy and citrus hops.  Really a well done beer.  Nice stuff. Thanks mar!

this beer pours a deep amber with a medium off white head.  the aroma is citrus and pine with a little smoke..  The flavor is  slightly dry in the beginning and dry on the backend.  This was very interesting brew.  Cheers!

Bottle, at RBNAG-09, courtesy of non-present KnutAlbert. Its a clear, orange-golden beer topped by a small, off-white head. Peaches, oranges and grapefruit on the nose, very pleasant, but in need of some malts. Maybe. The flavor has a little malty sweetness, but is dominating by the hops with peaches, grapefruit and orange. Lasting finish, medium bitter. Medium body, very cleverly carbonated. A really quenching one, and tasteful as well. 091107

bottle thanks to thirdeye11 who had to swim from scotland with a case of this stuff balanced on his head just so we can have some in texas.  poured amber with an off white head.  aroma was grain and pine with the flavor being the same plus some bitter.  body was medium with high carbonation.
Amber In color with a good sized beige head. Aroma is of hops, floral, malt. Taste is pfhops, light caramel, citrus. One of the better ambers Ive tried, but not as good as some seem to think it is.
Bottle. Clear and amber in color.  The head is decent and light beige in color.  The smell is hops, bread, caramel, malts, and decent.  The taste is caramel, hops, malts, biscuity, and ok.
Cask (Bitter Virtue, Southampton) - Copper coloured. Hoppy and biscuity aroma with hints of caramel. Hoppy and bitter taste with pine needles, toffee, caramel and grapefruit. Nicely balanced.
Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Notes of citrus, toasted biscuits, warm runny caramel, and malt. Not really bringing anything new to the table. Watery mouthfeel.

Bottle.Pours a deep, rich amber with a thick, full head of light beige.  Aroma is piercing hops with notes of sharp grapefruit, slick pine, and a touch of woodsy malt.  Flavor is an interesting mix of sweet rose and mollified hops, with bits of grapefruit and a touch of pine.  Hardly any malt backbone to this one; funny its an amber.  Decent mouthfeel.  Not bad; Im glad I bought a four-pack of this.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Had this one at the Pre-ZBF 2010. Copper colored brew. Nice hoppy aroma. Flavor is hoppy and malty. Very drinkable.
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, a copper colored pour with a hoppy pine needle aroma, flavors of caramel , cheesy malt,sour bitter finish
Bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  Pours with a large, off-white head that leaves good lace. Amber body. Aroma is hoppy with caramel. Taste is caramel, nutshells and bitter. Light bubbles. Dry.

Poured from bottle. HUGE nose of grapefruit and resin. Dark, attractive dark red-gold color and a nice head. Some scattered lace. Dynamite flavor, pungent with hops and with a nice toasty malt edge. Brewdogs production may be uneven, but I think theyve nailed this one.
Bottled. The aroma has citric hops, little caramel malts. Clear, amber coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is bitter, hoppy, citric, has some maltiness. Dry finish. Nice.

bottle thanks to thirdeye11,  deep ruby/amber with a nice cream head.  big tropical hops, tangerine and melon along with sweet caramel malts in the back.  very smooth on the palate with a great tropical hop flavor and a caramel malt finish.

(12oz bottle) pours deep reddish-amber with huge lasting head that coats the glass quite well. Nose of grass, sweet malt, cream, tangerine, and bread. Taste of toasty caramel, clean sweet malts, bread, light grapefruit bitterness with a medium-thin body that is creamy and delicious.

Bottle picked up at StateLine. Recommended by matt.  I have never been a fan of ambers but here we go. Nice pour (snifter).... Red in color, nice two finger head. Good pine aroma. Taste is a little on the watery side. Malty with a strong hoppy backbone. Metalic taste. Not bad at all for a 5 percent beer. Thanks matt!
On tap at Stone.  Clear golden with a creamy white head.  Citrus, caramel, and grapefruit aroma and taste with a smooth palate.

Pours an orange/red color.  not getting a lot of the malt and roast notes that I expect from an amber.  seems to be hoppier than it should be too.  If I hadnt read the label, I probably would have liked it more.  A pretty good pale ale in my mind.  Floral with a nice bite to it.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2012 [330ml bottle from my wife - cheers!] Once again Im offended by a Brewdog beer before I open the bottle - why they want to fill the bottle label with text hurling abuse at their customers is beyond me.  The gratuitous swearing is a turn-off too.  Its lucky they make decent beer really otherwise I for one wouldnt be buying them.  This ones a deep bronzey-amber with a cappuccino head and a slight fizz.  Its dominated by pine resin with lots of sweet lime and some grapefruit too.  Theres a touch of spice tingling on the tongue, and some sweet chocolatey malt in the background.  The moderate bitterness is well balanced by the sweet malt and a rich satisfying mouthfeel with a slightly dry finish.  It leaves you with a big smile on your face, wanting more.  Great stuff!

Very thick, cream-yellow head, slowly collapsing leaving lace over clear deep-amber beer. Thick C-hops, with caramel, banana and mango aromas. Superb. Very dry, peppery hops with very watered-down caramel flavour. Finish is hoppy and dry. Bit light palate, false (malt)syrupy impression, with a near-sticky ending. "Iconoclastic amber ale", they call it. Couldnt have put it better myself.

On tap at Stone Bistro.  Pours a nice reddish amber with creamy off-white head.  Citrusy hops, malt, light fruit, and bread in the aroma.  Flavor is similar, except lighter on the hops, and more caramel and bread.  Nice beer, tasty and drinkable.

Gave the cask version a miss at Leicester knowing it would turn up sooner or later...and sure enough here it is. Bottle from The Wine Cellars. Brilliant ruby with a slim, tenacious cream head and lacework aplenty. The kind of lush tropical-hoppy aroma Ive come to expect from The Dog; grapefruit juice, lychees, strawberry Chewits. Hopped-up, drying, tropical and husky on the palate like a HTDC shandy; big notes of grapefruit, tonic water, high cocoa and caramel. A notch more balancing malt sweetness and body would have been good, but Im nit-picking. Quality.

A really good clean tasting crisp slightly hoppy amber ale. Aroma oozes sharp fruit, bit of grapefruit and orange. The appearance is pretty much perfect consisting of bright orange amber colour, carbontion and a clear visibility. Yellow off white foamy head with good lacing. The palate is smooth on the tongue and quite light. The taste is crisp citrus fruit with a bitter taste. It has a slight sweet hint too.

when i think Amber ale, im bored, but Brewdog wakes and shakes this style up!! .. Pours out a dark orange, with medium bubbly white foam, lacing is also good .. aroma of light citrus, orange peel, pine cone - big for an amber .. very smooth, Watt was hittin them hard all night! .. Good stuff, and damned enjoyable.. .. No actually the boy is quite astute. I really am trying to kill him, but so far unsuccessfully. Hes quite wily, like his old man.

Tap at the Ginger Man, NYC. Pours a truly gorgeous ruby-red with a lingering white head. Nose is heavy on the hops, piney. Flavor is more balanced, with some earthy, sweet malts to counter the hops. Medium bodied with nice carbonation. Finish is clean, mildly dry with some bitterness. Quite good.

0,33 l bottle, bought at PreZBF Festival, Belgium.
What an appearance!!! Clear, deep amber beer with a huge, foamy but creamy tan head. And the aroma.. Fine citrussy hop perfume comes in the first second, after that arrives the caramel, some toasry aroma, grape and fine citrusses like grapefruit, orange peel. Alluring me to taste it....Medium bodied one with a powerful fruity hop flavor. Citrusses and grape, edible floral.flowery hops. Caramel and malt give the base for the resiny games of hops. Dry, floral aftertaste. Characteristic, hoppy amber one, yumm!

Tap at Spuyten Duyvil. Poured a rich red amber with a thin off white head. Nose is big simcoe and chinook hops. Lots of caramel flavor. The mouthful is a bit thin but that adds to the drinkability. This is a great red beer. Its hoppy and bitter with sweet caramel but its so non offensive.

The appearance is a nicve ruby red, off white head.  The aroma is flowers, citrus, very nice.  The flavor is floral, citrusy, caramel.  The hops totally win the day with this beer.  The finish is earthy hops (where the hell did they come from?),  floral hops.  Medium bodied.  Very nice overall.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2010 Cask. Leicester Beer Festival 2010. Sprucey hope overload going on here. Very bitter. Delicious. Ar8 Ap4 Ta9 Pa5 Ov19
Rate #2 Cask. The Pub, Leicester. Thin off-white head, clear dark brown body with a ruby red tinge. Aroma is blackcurrant, citrus, pine resin and caramel. Bitter, with delicate sweet notes. Soft mouthfeel, dry finish, slight oiliness. Ar7 Pa4 Ta7 Pa4 Ov15 Later of the reviews is shown.

Bottle, 330ml. Copper appearance, slight, white, long lasting head.
Citrus hops on the aroma, smells very fresh.
Sweet summer fruits as well as the obvious pine and grapefruit flavours from the hops.
