Pleasantly carbonated, I can imagine this as a very enjoyable session beer.

Bottle. Ruby pour, off white head. 
Smooth yet strong aroma of hops. Very fresh.
Flavour is fresh, subtle bitter hops, lasting quit long.
Quite nice, especially as a session beer,  why isnt this in all the bars instead of all those boring pilseners?
Bottle Low fluffy white quickly disappearing head. Clear red body. Malty hoppy dried fruit aroma. Heavily carbonated nutty malty dried fruit aroma with a long aftertaste.

Bottle at 3rd pre-ZBF after-tasting. Pours a clear ruby red with a thin off-white head. Aroma is hoppy fruity and with cherries. Flavor is dry, bitter, slightly watery and fruity with some spices. Quite nice.
Bottle @ Pre ZBF 2010. Pours copperish golden, piney hop nose, citrusfruits. Great bitterness lingers in my nostrils for hours. A session beer for hopaholics.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2011 Bottle from Tesco & BrewDog Online store. Bitter hoppy Aroma. Reddish medium brown colour with frothy head. Very complex flavour including hops wood and mixed fruit. Quite smooth with lingering hoppy aftertaste.  Another interesting one from Brewdog. Also found it in cask form at The Bon Accord. Much darker colour and smoother but taste not so sophisticated - more simple coffee chocolate.
Bottle at pre-ZBF 2010 in Ruddervoorde, poured by Martin.  Copper with an edge head and big lacing.  Aroma of scotch pine, taste has citrus, light fruit, nice hops.  Good brew

Cask-conditioned at the Portcullis, Clifton, Bristol 28/02/10. Deep amber in colour with a slight, off-white head. Big hoppy aroma of resin and citrus, with some summer fruits in the background. Easy drinking, with sweet malts balancing further citrus hops and a dry finish with a hint of pine. Excellent.
Dark amber with a off-white head. Fruity, pines, with a nice malt note. Drinkability at its best. Perfect bitter session beer.

Cask (handpump) at the Wenlock Arms, Islington, 31 July 2009. Massive leafy hop aroma. Lots of grapefruit, pine and flowery notes too. Maybe slightly less on the palate but still big hops in every way except stickiness.  Bags of bitterness. And unlike some hop bombs the mouthfeel remains light but firm, making for a hugely drinkable beer. Fantastic stuff.
Tap at the Tokyo Real Ale Festival. Nice hop aroma, great balance. Hops are aromatic but restrained. Very drinkable beer.

@tap at Tokyo Real Ale Festival (not Real Ale though!). Dark amber color. Very defined nose of apples and cotton candy. Absolutely lovely! Med-body with cotton candy, well balanced, but not as defining as the nose. Moderately hopped finish. Yum.

Bottle.  Amber red with a thin foam.  Aromas are bubblegum, peach and grapefruit with some pine.  Berries with some lemon.  Flavours are floral, dry and hoppy with grapefruit pith bitterness.  Has a long resinous aftertaste.  Very nice.

Bottle at Bishops Arms Malmö.
Clear amber coloured with a medium sized off white head.
Fruity aroma of hops, peaches, grass and pine needles.
Fruity flavour of hops, grass and grape fruits.
Dry hoppy finish.

Cask Stillage at Formby Hall, Atherton 29/01/2010
Big resiny hop aroma. Small white head. Mid brown coloured and very hoppy with a pine flavour. A little dryness in a bitter lasting finish.

Botte.

Pours dark redbrown.

Hoppy aroma of caramell and cookies.
Taste of grapefruit, butter and malt.

Bottle. Nice red color. Lousy head. Sweet hoppy aroma of grapefruit and strawberries. The taste is hoppy. Lots of grapefruit and some bitterness in the finish. Kind of light bodied beer. Refreshing and easy to drink.
ambrata limpida buonja schiuma buona persitenza naso  luppolato fruttato citrico agrumato tamarindo anche caramello finale secco luppolato intenso
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear amber - white head. High malty, roasted, bulldog, nice hoppy, peachy, fruity, piney, grassy, toasted. Pleasant.

Tasting at PapsøsAmber color. Wonderful hop aroma, fruity, with sharp grapefruit and a hint of passion fruit. Fairly good caramel flavor and very good hopping; actually the beer is limited by having a too dry mouthfeel and finish, while the hopping is gorgeous.

Ive had this cask and bottle, this is a bottle rate. The more I drink it, the more I like it. Its the huge hop flavour and aroma but the mellow bitter that I love. Its a cool beer with loads of fruity, floral flavour and a bready-berries malty body.

Bottled (BB 12/2010, batch #454)
Deep red-amber color, small off-white head. Very hoppy juicy aroma: pine needles and mango. Starts quite watery, a bit sweet. Then quite hoppy, lots of pine needles and conifers. Plesantly hoppy, although quite simple. I like that this is only 5 %.
Clear amber with atiny off white head. Hoppy aroma with pine and grapefruitss. Flavour was hoppy with notes of toasted malt, pine and grapefruits. Finished bitter.

[33cl bottle, Home, 10/01/10] Wonderful floral bouquet aroma accompanied by hints of biscuity malts. Medium sweet with moderate bitterness. Smooth, crisp mouthfeel. Gentle carbonation. Superbly drinkable. A very good beer. If there was a touch more going on with the taste it would be an excellent beer.

Bottled. An amber beer with a off-white head. The aroma has notes of grapefruity hops, malt, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, grapefruity hops, leading to a very bitter finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.

33 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden dark orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is solid peachy hops fruity. Distinct peachy and dry hops flavoured. Sweet and crisp hops fruity flavoured into the far finish. Smooth and fruity lasting impression.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a clear amber with an off-white head. Lovely peachy hop aroma. Medium body, dry fruit and caramel but completely dominated by the good American hops. Dry but not overly bitter finish. 100110

Several bottles ordered from the brewery website, drunk in Nov and Dec 09. Coppery amber colour with a magnolia head. One of the best beers Brewdog have created, this is bursting with North American hop aromas and flavours. And its only 5%! "Iconoclastic amber ale"? Hell yeah, this is showing other people the way. Clean tasting with a great hop aftertaste, balanced and it smells so good you dont want to start your sip, just keep breathing in the heady aroma. Should get bonus points for their most aggressive label text yet. This is going to be a regular in my kitchen for a long time to come.
Bottle at Craigs house. Brown and smooth, nice beer. Would definately have again.

(Bottled) Clear amber with a medium, frothy and lacy head. Aroma of woody cat-pee-style hops and some caramely malt. Flavor is caramely maltiness combined with citric-woody hops, and stingy cat pee. Light to medium body, medium carbonation, a bit thin. A watered-down amber ale with cat pee added - not my session brew for sure.

Reddish amber colour with a small head. 

Fruity, malty nose with grapefruit, pine, caramel and that fresh hoppy smell. 

Fruity, hoppy taste with notes of caramel, with citrussy hops in the finish.

Slightly malt feel! and Very Drinkable!

A layer of fine, tan bubbles over a orangey golden body. Beautiful aroma of sweet grapefruit, apricot and peach, backed by a mild scent of caramel. Flaworwise it is much of the same. Hoppy, with lots of inviting tropical fruits, and a refined, caramelly maltiness in the background.  Light to medium body strenght. Quite filling for a 5 percenter. Lasting, citrus hoppy ending. Yummie!

(Cask at Rake, Soutwark, London, 25 Nov 2009) Reddish amber colour with brief head. Fruity, malty nose with grapefruit, pine, chocolate, caramel and lots of fresh hops. Malty, fruity, hoppy taste with notes of caramel, toffee, chocolate, grapefruit and piney, citrussy hops in the finish. More than medium body, balanced sweetness. Very nice beer with an impressive hop presence.

330 ml can [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2009, Vatlandsvåg. Amber body with a decent beige head. Aroma is American hops citric (peaches/apricot). The flavor is mild and citric  fruity, very smooth with a balanced bitterness. Easy drinkable with a mild, pronounced flavor. Nice, bitter finish. Somewhere between an American amber and a saison.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2009 Cask - The Bull, Horton Kirby. A dark, ruddy amber coloured beer with a fine, creamy, slightly off-white head. Absolutely cracking tropical grapefruit aromas & citrus hops with some peach in there. Bit dissapointed with the flavour off the back of the aroma. Theres some comparatively mild citrus notes, a bit of grass, sweet caramel tones and a final hint of nut. Thin to medium, slight carbonation, farily succinct, crisp and quaffable finish.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2010 Cask @ Bon Accord. Dark amber colour, tan head. Aroma of flowery hops, and hints of biscuit malts. Flavour of resin hops, grapefruit. Very bitter and fairly dry. Slightly malty. Good one.

Again cask @ Bon Accord. Aroma is very juicy, fruity. Flavour is bitter and caramel malts. +.3

Oh yes, what a beer! Interestingly I tried Nanny State a couple days before this, and it seems to me that Nanny State is essentially a low alcohol super heavy hop version of this very beer, as the Hop flavour in this brew is almost identical. Anyhoo. Looks great in the glass, nothing overly fancy but a great deep rusty copper colour with a light tan head, which is quite creamy looking. The aroma is just sublime, perhaps not as sublime as Punk IPA on draught, but still great. Really spicy aroma with all the floral, wild strawb, orange, grapefruit notes you could ask for. The flavour is excellent, this is as close to a Stone beer in terms of flavour that Ive ever come in the UK. It has that same blend of Spice, earth and mineral that Stone has, Ive not tasted that harmonious blend in many other beers, or at least not as close as this. Flavour is pink grapefruit, floral, resinous, spicy maybe ginger? Some citrus but more like sour blood orange. Then in comes slate, mineral, pepper, earth almost a burnt acrid flavour in the background. Palate is great, conditioning is great, could be a little fuller bodied, but Im not gonna gripe about that, thats just a personal thing, body still remains creamy and balanced. Overall a great beer, quite possibly my favourite Brewdog beer so far, is it because it reminds me alot of a US beer - I suspect so - but that doesnt detract from Brewdog, as it shows we here in the UK can Punch at that kind of weight class, its just a shame theres so few Breweries with this kind of assertive, gutsy approach. The beer still tastes quintessentially British/Scottish (dont want to step on any toes here) but has some serious power and flavour behind it. Reminds me alot of Stones "Levitation." This is possibly a landmark in UK brewing, have I gone hyperbole mad? Perhaps, but this is what good beer is all about.

Bottle, 5% ABV, RBNAG 2009 in Vatlandsvåg. Orange to amber colour, moderate head. Intense and lovely aroma of American hops (Amarillo?), notes of peaches, apricots and tropical fruits. The flavour is somewhat less impressive than the aroma, but still good. Notes of peaches, but quite dry. Decent hops in the finish. The mouthfeel is a bit thin though.

Gravity caak at Oxford Beer Festival. Copper red with a lively beige head. Knock your socks off aroma of fresh hops. Piney grapefruit flavours dominate the hop profile with a full bodied toffee malt backbone. My beer of the festival.

Cask (gravity) @ Wenlock Arms, 26 Wenlock Road, London, Greater London England N1 7TA.Clear medium to dark amber color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, light heavy hoppy, grapefruit, orange. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, and a dry finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. IMO a very good session beer ;O)) [20090731]

Cask handpull at The Rake.  Nelson Sauvin hops all over this.  Really hoppy on the aroma.  A beautiful deep red russet colour too.  Very drinkable, a little sweet on the malts, but then they do balance the hops pretty well.  Very drinkable and the hops are lovely.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Slightly hazy amber with a small white head. Rich fruity and floral aroma. Sweet caramel flavour with floral notes and very bitter. 7-3-8-3-15
Cask at Youll Never Walk Alone, Kolding, 17 February 2010. Red copper with a small, but lasting white head. Floral, fruity and slightly wooden hops. Sweetish fruity hop flavour with Nelson Sauvin character. Firm bitterness. Big and creamy mouthfeel. 7-4-8-5-15

Bottle from James the brewer.
Glowing gold/ruby beer. A fantastic hoppy aroma. Flowers, dust.

 The first sip confirms this  lovely hoppiness, yet there is enough malt and body to cope with it. This may be a test batch- but it does not need any adjustments if you ask me. Peaches, Jaffa oranges, dusty finish. Yummy.

A few bottles thanks to James had at home. Aroma is massivly hoppy, similar to how to disapear with the intence citrusy lemon and herbal grassy bitterness, the malt character is hidden but theres defo some american caramalt influance. Taste is far more balanced than expected, toffee caramel caramalt, big piney resiny citrus hops, good drying bitterness in the finish. Very tasty and drinkable stuff.

A Mes rate: bottle at the ever brilliant Chris Os Pre GBBF Extravaganza, then again at The Wenlock.Fanbloodytastic. Waht can I say. Nelson Sauvin fest all round. Tropical, citric, faint cat pee, all I could want from this glorious hop. Amazing dry then fruity then bitter as hell finish. Brilliant stuff once again from BrewDog.

Cask, gravity at the White Horse, Hedgerley, Bucks 08-08-09 on leg seven of the Thames Tipple   The landlord Kevin very kindly brought us out a half pint of this to sample, I then had another half before we left the pub as it came on. Pours copper with a  slight haze and an off white head. This had the most magnificent hoppy aroma, grapefruit was all over your nostrils like a rash. Flavours were very grapefruit, incredibly fruity and with long dry finish, nice full on bitterness, so tangy and tasty, all of our group loved this beer and so did I.  A9 A3 F8 P4 Ov17  4.1

Nice lace. Aroma is Aroma is bigtime fruity and flowery hops alng with some caramel. Flavour is bigtime fruityness along with some berries, grass, caramel malts and slight nuttyness. Some rather plummy notes as well.

Cassk @ Halfway House, Edinburgh (and later @ Bow Bar, Edinburgh).
Pours deep amber with a small, creamy, off-white head. Aroma has strawberries, peach, pine and subdued caramel. Prickly, great carbonation, super dry mouthfeel. Flavour is just great as well. Soft, yet hard bitterness, resiny hops, strawberries, nuts, peach, grapefruity and pine. Caramel background. Super malt balance with a light citric touch to the finish. Very nice!

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2012 Cask at Bow bar (cellar run) ... Deep brown ...light sweet pine hop resin nose... Oh My god ones again this is in your face Hop tastic.. big big grapefruit hop ... very brigh but a dry linger ... light sweet pine resins...and very very drinkable... 3.6 

Tk 2 Bow bar on cask 7/8 of a pint:-) ... Copper ... nice white head .. big grapefruithop nose ... again load of grapefruit in flavour ... Loadfs of bitterness ... quite drying ... little pine ...crammed with hop... soft but full mouth feel... bitterness builds way too much for me 3.4

tk 3 bottle at home ... brown ... roast toffee little woody nose ...soft roast... grapefruit ... some pine ... quite bitter


Tk4 bottle at home ... dark copper ... light beight head ... sweet toffee pine resin nose ... big in face hop ... grapefruit ... pine ... juicy but bitter linger ... and bitter too much for me. 3.4

keg at cloisters ... deep pink amber ... soft sweet juicy pine... big bitter front ... loads of grapefrfuit ... little toffee malt ... good bit little too fizy ... little to bitter. 3.4
